diagnosis: High‑severity hard impact at Joint 1 combined with elevated temperature indicates possible motor overload, thermal stress, or emerging bearing/motor driver degradation immediately after calibration.
inspection_steps:
- Verify Joint 1 motor temperature against nominal operating range
- Inspect J1 housing, cabling, and connectors for heat discoloration or mechanical deformation
- Check post‑calibration offsets for drift caused by impact
- Review torque logs before and after the event for abnormal spikes
- Manually rotate J1 (power-off) to assess for roughness or binding
maintenance_actions:
- Perform detailed thermal inspection of J1 motor and driver module
- Re-run full J1 calibration and compare results to baseline
- Lubricate or replace J1 bearing assembly if friction is detected
- Validate cooling airflow or liquid‑cooling channels for blockage
- Clear any debris or mechanical interference around J1 work envelope
safety_clearance:
- Lock out and tag out robot before contact inspection
- Allow motor to cool to safe-handling temperature
- Verify no residual stored energy on J1 drive
- Confirm collision zone is clear of obstructions before functional testing
return_to_service:
- Perform low‑speed J1 motion test and confirm stable temperature rise profile
- Validate torque behavior under nominal load
- Run collision‑avoidance sensor self‑test
- Approve return to operation only after temperatures and torque readings remain stable for one full duty cycle

diagnosis: High‑severity hard impact on J1 immediately after joint calibration indicates probable mechanical shock to the base axis, with risk of encoder offset, bearing preload shift, or mounting surface disturbance.
inspection_steps:
- Power down and engage lockout/tagout
- Visually inspect J1 housing, base casting, and cable routing for impact marks or deformation
- Check J1 mechanical backlash and verify brake holding torque
- Inspect encoder coupling and confirm zero-position alignment
- Review internal collision logs for torque spike patterns
maintenance_actions:
- Perform J1 encoder re-homing and compare with pre-calibration reference
- Re-torque J1 mounting bolts to manufacturer specifications
- Lubricate J1 bearing surfaces if intervals allow post-impact servicing
- Run J1 motion test at reduced speed to detect abnormal vibration or increased motor current
- If misalignment > acceptable threshold, perform full J1 axis recalibration
safety_clearance:
- Confirm no structural cracks or loosened hardware
- Validate encoder readings remain stable across full J1 sweep
- Ensure torque values normalize during test cycles
- Supervisor sign-off required due to high-severity event
return_to_service:
- Resume operation at 50% speed for first verification cycle
- Monitor torque and current trends for minimum 30 minutes runtime
- If no anomalies occur, restore full duty cycle and log event resolution

diagnosis: Repeated high‑severity emergency stops at J1 within 24 hours suggest human-triggered safety intervention or abnormal motion at the joint immediately after calibration.
inspection_steps:
- Verify E-stop button condition and rule out mechanical sticking
- Inspect J1 cabling, connectors, and harness routing for drag or snag points
- Review motion logs for abnormal J1 acceleration or unexpected command inputs
maintenance_actions:
- Recalibrate J1 torque/position limits to confirm post-maintenance integrity
- Test J1 motion at reduced speed to detect binding or overshoot
- Update E-stop circuit check and confirm correct reset behavior
safety_clearance:
- Confirm no physical obstructions in J1 workspace
- Validate E-stop system electrical integrity via panel test
- Ensure operators understand reset procedure and recent maintenance status
return_to_service:
- Perform supervised trial cycle at low speed
- Monitor torque trace for stability and absence of spikes
- Approve full-speed operation only after three clean cycles with no additional stops

diagnosis: High-severity emergency stop on J1 with elevated torque load suggests abrupt external interference or operator-triggered E-stop during active motion; potential transient joint stress despite recent calibration.
inspection_steps:
- Inspect J1 mechanical housing for impact marks or misalignment
- Verify encoder feedback consistency on J1 following the E-stop
- Check cable harness and connector integrity at J1
- Review E-stop button logs to confirm if manually activated
- Inspect surrounding workspace for obstructions or foreign objects
maintenance_actions:
- Perform J1 torque sensor health check and compare against post-calibration baselines
- Re-run joint homing and verify repeatability
- Re-seat or replace any loose or damaged connectors at J1
- Update incident record with observed physical or electrical anomalies
safety_clearance:
- Validate E-stop circuit continuity and correct reset behavior
- Confirm workspace is clear of operators and obstructions
- Ensure robot controller reports no additional safety faults
return_to_service:
- Execute slow-speed motion test on J1 under supervision
- Verify torque values remain within expected ranges during motion
- Approve full-speed operation only after stable performance is confirmed
